awd_titl_txt: The Role of Catalyst Microstructure in Gas Diffusion Electrosynthesis of C2+ Products
awd_abstract_narration:
Professor Matthew Kanan of Stanford University is supported by the Chemical Catalysis (CAT) Program of the Division of Chemistry to investigate the relationship between the structure of copper catalysts and their catalytic properties for the electrochemical conversion of carbon monoxide (CO). The project involves the use of electrochemical cells employing gas diffusion electrodes (GDEs), which maximize the transport of gases to and from the catalyst material and hence enable high product synthesis rates.  The ultimate goal is to convert carbon dioxide (CO2) to fuels and useful chemicals.  The technology to convert CO2 to CO is already available, but the subsequent conversion of CO into more useful chemicals and fuels via electrolysis is not well established.  The project focuses on means to enhance the performance of the copper catalyst material on the cathode, the electrode where CO is combined with electrons and protons to form products such as hydrocarbons, alcohols, or carboxylic acids.  The viability of using copper catalysts for scalable production of the desired product hinges on the ability to tailor its structure to maximize activity, selectivity, and durability.  The rapid growth and falling costs of renewable electricity have increased the attraction of using electricity to power the synthesis of fuels and chemicals from carbon dioxide and water.  The study of how microstructure affects performance in electrochemical CO conversion may unveil strategies for exploiting microstructure in other catalytic processes that are important to energy conversion and industrial chemical synthesis. To complement the research activities, the group engages in scientific outreach to local high school students by using electrochemical conversion demonstrations and lab modules to illustrate core chemical concepts and inspire students to pursue scientific careers.

Numerous structure - activity models have been proposed for Cu-catalyzed carbon dioxide and carbon monoxide reduction based on solution-phase studies at low current density. However, practical electrosynthesis will require operating at much higher current density using a GDE. It is unclear if the structure - activity relationships that have been elucidated in solution-phase electrolyses are applicable to Cu materials operating in GDEs at high current densities. Moreover, microstructural features that may influence the intrinsic catalytic properties of Cu materials are convoluted with the complex, heterogeneous architecture of the catalyst layer of GDEs, which typically is composed of catalyst particles, carbon particles, fluorinated polymers, and ionomers. The research in this project seeks to establish a methodology for elucidating microstructural effects on Cu catalysts operating in GDEs and disentangle these effects from morphological and mass transport phenomena that depend on the architecture of the GDE catalyst layer. New synthetic methods are developed to target well-defined Cu nanoparticles with controllable grain boundary density and geometry. The grain structures are mapped using transmission Kikuchi diffraction and other electron diffraction and x-ray diffraction techniques. Next, the catalytic activity of microstructurally variant samples is comprehensively evaluated in GDEs using custom electrochemical cells. These studies seek to identify correlations between grain boundaries and the activity or selectivity for specific C2+ products and assess how these correlations depend on current density/overpotential, electrolyte, and other parameters. In parallel, spray-coating procedures are developed to vary the thickness, porosity, and wettability of the catalyst layer of a GDE. These procedures are used to optimize the architecture of the GDE for high current density at minimal overvoltage and assess the relative importance of architecture vs catalyst microstructure in this regime.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Using electricity to power the conversion of CO2 into fuels and chemicals, a process known as CO2electrolysis, is a potential alternative to the use of fossil fuel resources. When powered by renewable electricity, CO2 electrolysis could offer substantial benefits including reduced greenhouse gas emissions, lower air pollution, and distributed production tailored to local renewable resources. The development of CO2electrolyzers is currently hindered by poor performance of catalyst materials at the cathode, the electrode that performs the CO2 reduction reaction wherein the fuel or chemical products are made by combining CO2 with electrons and protons from H2O. With currently available catalysts, CO2 reduction requires excessive voltage that results in energy losses. In addition to this problem, it is also difficult to control selectivity of CO2 reduction, especially with Cu catalysts that produce valuable multi-carbon products.   

To achieve high rates of product formation, gas diffusion electrodes are commonly used in CO2 electrolysis. These electrodes are composed of a carbon material with hydrophobic pores to facilitate gas transport. The catalyst materials that convert CO2 into products reside in a thin layer on top of the gas diffusion electrode. The goal of this project was to obtain fundamental design principles for gas diffusion electrode catalyst layers by investigating how the microstructure of the catalyst materials and the overall architecture of the catalyst layer affect the performance. Microstructure refers to the size and morphology of the catalyst particles and the presence of defects such as grain boundaries. The architecture of the catalyst layer refers to the complex 3-dimensional structure composed of the catalyst particles, electrolyte solution, and hydrophobic components that are included for gas transport. 

Toward these goals, the project yielded three significant outcomes: i) The project provided new insights into how grain boundaries can be utilized to improve the energy efficiency and selectivity of CO2 reduction. A combination of analytical techniques was used to obtain maps of electrocatalytic activity and grain structure with ~200 nm resolution on Au electrodes as model system. These experiments revealed that grain boundaries selectively enhance CO2 reduction activity but not H2O reduction. Based on analysis of electron diffraction patterns, the origin of this enhanced activity was attributed to a high density of surface steps arising from the accumulation of lattice dislocations near the grain boundaries. ii) The project showed that controlling the architecture of the catalyst layer is critical for optimizing the energy efficiency of electrolysis with gas diffusion electrodes. A method for preparing catalyst layers with greater control over the sizes of the catalyst particle and hydrophobic domains was developed and applied to study the effect of domain size on the energy efficiency and selectivity of carbon monoxide (CO) reduction. CO is the intermediate for CO2 conversion to multi-carbon products and pairing CO2-to-CO electrolysis with CO-to-multi-carbon product electrolysis has been identified as a potentially advantageous alternative to direct CO2 electrolysis to multi-carbon products. The results showed that confining the width of Cu catalyst domains to approximately 5 microns led to favorable gas, ion, liquid, and electron transport properties in the catalyst layer that enabled the use of high Cu catalyst loadings to reduce the voltage requirement and improve the selectivity for CO reduction to valuable products such as propanol. Smaller sizes for the Cu catalyst domains resulted in electrical insulation of a portion of the catalyst, which increased voltage demand, while larger domains resulted in gas transport limitations that lowered the selectivity. The methods to prepare catalyst layers with control over the size of catalyst and hydrophobic domains are likely to be applicable to other electrochemical technologies important for energy conversion applications. iii) A computational model of CO reduction in a gas diffusion electrode catalyst layer was developed to provide new insight into the mass transport and reaction processes that determine the performance metrics of CO reduction. The computational model was a high-fidelity continuum model that included rate equations for the key electrochemical reactions and the gas and ion transport processes. The model was validated by comparison to experimental data and then used to probe the effects of varying operational parameters of the electrolysis, including pressure, temperature, current density and gas flow rate. The results provide guidelines for optimizing gas diffusion electrode electrolysis by improving the catalyst properties and process conditions. 

By advancing design principles for electrochemical CO2 and CO conversion technologies, the project has a potential broader impact on efforts to reduce the environmental impact of chemical and fuel production and decouple them from fossil resources. In addition, the PI worked to improve the integration of energy conversion and the carbon management (natural carbon cycle and utilization of fossil resources) into undergraduate organic chemistry. By broadening the undergraduate curriculum to include these topics, students were given an additional perspective on the critical importance and power of chemistry to understanding diverse natural phenomena and addressing global challenges. 

 


Last Modified: 11/02/2022
Modified by: Matthew Kanan
por.por_txt_cntn:
Using electricity to power the conversion of CO2 into fuels and chemicals, a process known as CO2electrolysis, is a potential alternative to the use of fossil fuel resources. When powered by renewable electricity, CO2 electrolysis could offer substantial benefits including reduced greenhouse gas emissions, lower air pollution, and distributed production tailored to local renewable resources. The development of CO2electrolyzers is currently hindered by poor performance of catalyst materials at the cathode, the electrode that performs the CO2 reduction reaction wherein the fuel or chemical products are made by combining CO2 with electrons and protons from H2O. With currently available catalysts, CO2 reduction requires excessive voltage that results in energy losses. In addition to this problem, it is also difficult to control selectivity of CO2 reduction, especially with Cu catalysts that produce valuable multi-carbon products.   

To achieve high rates of product formation, gas diffusion electrodes are commonly used in CO2 electrolysis. These electrodes are composed of a carbon material with hydrophobic pores to facilitate gas transport.
